questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with painless hematuria and weight loss over the past six months. CECT reveals a 9 cm enhancing mass in the right kidney, with evidence of invasion into the renal vein. Histopathology shows cells with clear cytoplasm and a delicate network of vasculature. Which of the following is the most likely variant of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Clear cell renal cell carcinoma Explanation: The clinical presentation and histopathological findings are indicative of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (CCRCC). The size of the tumor and involvement of the renal vein indicate an advanced stage, underscoring the aggressive nature of CCRCC. Classification and salient features of variants of RCC RCC Variants Salient features Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (CCRCC (Option C) Most common variant Usually sporadic May be associated with the loss of chromosome 3p and a mutated von Hippel–Lindau gene Macroscopic appearance: solid, golden-yellow tumor with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Microscopy : cells have clear cytoplasm due to the presence of abundant lipids and glycogen, surrounded by a delicate network of vasculature. Papillary renal cell carcinoma (Option B) Second most common variant It can be further divided into Type 1 and Type 2 Type 1 has small basophilic cells and Type 2 is characterized by large eosinophilic cells. Type 1 has a better prognosis than type 2. Associated with mutations in the MET gene - chromosome 7, 17, or Y. Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (Option A) Arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. Microscopy: Characterized by large polygonal cells with prominent cell membranes and pale cytoplasm. Better prognosis compared to other types of RCC. Collecting duct carcinoma (Option D) Also known as Bellini duct carcinoma. Rare and aggressive form of RCC that arises from the collecting ducts in the renal medulla, hence centrally located. Poor prognosis Renal medullary carcinoma Rare and aggressive Associated with sickle cell trait in children Centrally located Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 1483

questions.question: A 70-year-old male with a history of hypertension is diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) after a CT scan reveals a 5 cm tumor confined to the right kidney. His renal function is normal, and there is no evidence of metastasis. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Partial Nephrectomy Explanation: In this patient's case, with a 5 cm tumor confined to the kidney and no evidence of metastasis, Partial Nephrectomy is the most appropriate initial treatment option. This approach will effectively manage the localized RCC while preserving renal function. Investigations for RCC: Ultrasound (USG) Initial Imaging Helps distinguish between solid and cystic masses Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) Investigation of choice for diagnosis and staging. MRI Superior at detecting tumor infiltration into the vein wall and the level of thrombus. Investigation of choice for detecting tumor thrombus Chest Imaging (CT or X-ray), Bone Scan To rule out metastases. Renal Biopsy Not routinely performed due to the risk of seeding and the high diagnostic accuracy of imaging. Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant. Surgical Management: Partial Nephrectomy (Option A) : Involves removing only the tumor while preserving the remainder of the kidney. Indications: T1 Disease(<7cm) Restricted to poles RCC in solitary functioning kidney Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim. Indications: Larger tumors or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible Ablative Techniques Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation: Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures. Indications: Patients who are not surgical candidates Patients with small tumors(T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm). Systemic Therapy (For advanced/ metastatic disease) Targeted Therapy Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib) mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus) Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab) Radical Nephrectomy (Option B) : This is more aggressive than necessary for a small, localized tumor, as it removes the entire kidney, leading to unnecessary loss of renal function. Radiofrequency Ablation (Option C) : Typically reserved for patients who are not surgical candidates, it's less effective than surgery for long-term tumor control in healthy patients. Targeted Therapy (Option D) : Used for metastatic or advanced RCC, it's not indicated as the initial treatment for a localized tumor with no evidence of metastasis. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 2091, 2092

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman is incidentally found to have a horseshoe kidney during an abdominal CT scan. She has no symptoms. Which of the following complications is she at highest risk for developing?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction Explanation: Horseshoe kidney increases the risk of PUJ obstruction due to the abnormal position of the kidneys and the associated vascular anomalies, which can compress the ureters and impair urine flow. Horseshoe Kidney Causes: During fetal development the kidneys fuse at their lower poles, forming a U-shaped structure. This fusion results in the inferior mesenteric artery preventing the ascent of the isthmus of the kidney to its normal position in the abdomen, leading to an abnormal location lower in the abdomen. Clinical Features: Mostly asymptomatic. Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones. Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) Hydronephrosis Hematuria Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain. Investigations: CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualization of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications. Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include : Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the "Hand Joining Sign." High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters. Treatment: Treatment depends on the presence and severity of symptoms: Asymptomatic Patients: Typically do not require treatment, but should be monitored periodically. Symptomatic Patients: UPJ Obstruction: Surgical intervention such as pyeloplasty Kidney Stones: Management may include conservative measures like increased fluid intake, medical therapy, or surgical removal UTIs: Treated with antibiotics, and preventive measures may be considered if infections are recurrent. Isthmus Management: The isthmus of the horseshoe kidney should not be divided surgically as it contains functional renal tissue. Pregnancy Considerations: A horseshoe kidney can lead to dystocia (difficult labor) due to the kidney's abnormal position. Renal cell carcinoma (Option B) : While the risk of renal cell carcinoma is slightly increased in patients with a horseshoe kidney, it is not as common as UPJ obstruction. Renal artery stenosis (Option C) : Renal artery stenosis is not directly associated with horseshoe kidney, though the abnormal anatomy can complicate vascular supply, it is not the most common complication. Nephroptosis (Option D) : Nephroptosis (a floating kidney) does not occur in horseshoe kidneys because the kidneys are fused and anchored in place

questions.question: A newborn presents with abdominal distension and respiratory distress. Ultrasound reveals bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple small cysts. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis is incorrect?

options.A: It follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance
options.B: The gene involved is the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 7
options.C: USG shows enlarged, echogenic kidneys, with poor corticomedullary differentiation
options.D: Hepatic fibrosis is the cause of death

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The gene involved is the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 7. Explanation: The clinical scenario suggests that the patient has a case of Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) , previously called Infantile Polycystic Kidney Disease. PKHD1 (Polycystic Kidney and Hepatic Disease 1), is located on the short (p) arm of chromosome 6, not chromosome 7. Infantile Polycystic Kidney Disease. Inheritance Autosomal recessive (Option A) Gene Involved PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6p12.2 (Option B) Clinical Presentation Abdominal distension Respiratory distress Bilaterally enlarged kidneys Multiple small cysts (primarily in collecting ducts) Progressive renal insufficiency Extrarenal Manifestations Congenital hepatic fibrosis Portal hypertension Pulmonary Fibrosis and hypoplasia Diagnosis Ultrasound: Enlarged, echogenic kidneys with poor corticomedullary differentiation (Option C) Genetic testing for PKHD1 mutations Management Inevitably fatal Supportive care can be given Main causes of death Congenital Hepatic fibrosis (Option D) Respiratory insufficiency Renal failure Reference: Pubmed Radiopedia

questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the investigations and treatment of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease? of fluid from cysts in ADPKD

options.A: CECT is the investigation of choice for ADPKD
options.B: IVP may show a "spider leg" or "bell-shaped" appearance in ADPKD
options.C: Rovsing's operation is the gold standard for management which involves the opening and evacuation
options.D: Treatment is only done when cysts are overdistended causing pain, hemorrhage & infection

questions.explanation: opening and evacuation of fluid from cysts in ADPKD Correct Answer: C) Rovsing's operation is the gold standard for management which involves the opening and evacuation of fluid from cysts in ADPKD. Explanation: The gold standard management for ADPKD is renal transplantation , not Rovsing operation. Management of ADPKD primarily involves a ‘wait and watch policy’. Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease- Investigations and Management Investigations Investigation of choice: CECT (Option A) Ultrasound: Confirms the presence of cysts IVP (Intravenous Pyelogram): Spider leg/Bell-shaped appearance (Option B) Bubble appearance Swiss-cheese appearance Blood urea and serum creatinine : Elevated Urine: Shows low specific gravity Management Wait and watch initially. Surgical intervention is required only after cysts get overdistended causing pain, hemorrhage, and infection. (Option D) Gold Standard: Renal Transplantation Rovsing's Operation (Option C) : Deroofing of Cyst in ADPKD. The kidney is exposed. The cyst is opened. The fluid is evacuated. US-guided aspiration & Laparoscopic aspiration is commonly done as a simpler approach Once renal failure sets in, initial hemodialysis followed by bilateral nephrectomy is done and later renal transplantation can be planned Other eponyms named after Niels Thorkild Rovsing: Rovsing's Syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine in the horseshoe kidney produces abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Rovsing Sign: Pain in right iliac fossa on pressing left iliac fossa seen in appendicitis. Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 994, 995

questions.question: A 6-month-old child undergoes a micturating cystourethrogram for suspected vesicoureteric reflux. The radiologist notes reflux into the renal pelvis with mild distention of the collecting system. Which grade of vesicoureteric reflux does this finding represent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Grade III Explanation: According to the grading system for vesicoureteric reflux, Grade III is characterized by reflux with mild distention of the renal pelvis and ureter. Grade Description Chances of spontaneous resolution of VUR I Reflux into non-dilated ureter 80% II Reflux into the pelvicalyceal system 80% III Mild to moderate dilatation of the ureter with reflux into the pelvicalyceal system 50% IV Blunting of fornix with reflux into the pelvicalyceal system 20% V Dilated and tortuous ureter with reflux into the pelvicalyceal system 0-5%

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and a palpable kidney mass in the loin region. Further, the patient is diagnosed with vesicoureteric reflux on both sides. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the management of this condition?

options.A: Most cases resolve spontaneously without treatment
options.B: The investigation of choice is Intravenous Pyelogram
options.C: Symptomatic cases require surgical correction via ureteric reimplantation
options.D: Severe cases may require nephrectomy and renal transplantation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The investigation of choice is Intravenous Pyelogram Explanation: Investigation of choice for vesicoureteral reflux is Micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). Vesicoureteric reflux Causes Congenital: Commonly associated with posterior urethral valve Acquired: Trauma due to surgery or intervention Clinical Features Recurrent UTI and Pyelonephritis Palpable mass in the loin Renal failure in bilateral cases Complications Renal scarring if not managed in symptomatic patients Investigations Micturating cystourethrogram (IOC) Intravenous urography Urine microscopy and C/S Blood urea and serum creatinine Treatment Grade I to III- Antibiotic Prophylaxis as it resolves spontaneously in most patients. (Option A) Grade IV to V- Antibiotics + Surgery Only symptomatic patients require surgical correction via ureteric reimplantation. (Option B) Surgery: Ureterovesicoplasty Ureteric reimplantation (Lich-Gregoir technique) STING Operation (Endoscopic) Severe cases may require nephrectomy and renal transplantation. (Option D) Reference: 1. SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1028, 1029 2. Pubmed

questions.question: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric urology clinic by her mother, who reports that the child has "never been dry" since birth. The mother notes that urine dribbles continuously via the vagina, but the child can also pass urine normally. An intravenous urogram is performed which is attached below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.C: Ectopic ureter from duplicated collecting system

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ectopic ureter from duplicated collecting system Explanation: The clinical presentation and radiological image support the diagnosis of bilateral complete duplication of ureter , opening into the vagina. Epidemiology MC congenital anomaly of the upper urinary tract Usually unilateral, common on the left side; More common in females Types Incomplete duplication Bifid ureter Complete duplication Weigert Meyer’s Rule- Upper pole ureter is caudal and medial compared to lower pole ureter. Clinical Features In Males

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging reveals a cystic dilation near the ureteral orifice within the bladder. Which of the following best describes the underlying condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ureterocele Explanation: The boy's recurrent UTIs and palpable abdominal mass, along with imaging showing cystic dilation near the ureteral orifice, are indicative of a ureterocele . Ureterocele is the congenital dilation of the distal ureter within the bladder wall. It can obstruct urine flow, leading to recurrent UTIs and hydronephrosis. Treatment often involves surgical correction to relieve the obstruction. Ureterocele: 1. Types: Simple Ureterocele (Intravesical - 20%): Found entirely within the bladder and associated with a single ureter. It is less complex and easier to manage. Ectopic Ureterocele (80%) : Extends beyond the bladder and often involves a duplicated ureter. This is more complicated due to its location, which may involve the bladder neck, or urethra. 2. Causes: Congenital anomaly caused by an obstruction in the development of the distal ureter during fetal growth, leading to cystic dilation at the ureteral orifice. 3. Clinical Features: Recurrent Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)/ Urosepsis. Unilateral Hydroureteronephrosis. Palpable Abdominal Mass: Particularly in children, where a distended bladder or large ureterocele might be felt as a mass. 4. Investigations: Ultrasound (USG): The first-line imaging modality, revealing hydroureteronephrosis and a cystic structure in the bladder corresponding to the ureterocele. Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU): Demonstrates a filling defect in the bladder caused by the ureterocele. Cystoscopy: Allows direct visualization of the ureterocele as a cystic structure that enlarges and collapses with urine flow in the bladder. Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP): The investigation of choice (IOC) for diagnosing ureterocele, showing the characteristic "adder head" or "cobra head" appearance due to the dilated ureter within the bladder. 5. Treatment: The treatment approach depends on the type of ureterocele: Intravesical Ureterocele: Typically managed with an incision over the cyst wall to allow free flow of urine into the bladder, relieving the obstruction. Ectopic Ureterocele: More complex, often requiring surgical excision of the ureterocele and reimplantation of the ureter into the bladder to correct the abnormal anatomy. 6. Associated Congenital Abnormalities: The most common congenital abnormality of the upper urinary tract is ureteral duplication , which can be associated with ureterocele. Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) , another common congenital abnormality, may occur in conjunction with ureterocele, particularly in cases involving ureteral duplication. Bladder diverticulum (Option B) : A bladder diverticulum is an outpouching of the bladder wall, not a cystic dilation of the ureter near the bladder. It usually does not obstruct the ureteral orifice. Ectopic ureter (Option C) : An ectopic ureter does not open into the bladder in its usual location. While it can cause obstruction and infection, it does not present as a cystic dilation within the bladder. Vesicoureteral reflux (Option D) : This condition

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with right-sided flank pain and persistent hematuria. An intravenous urogram is done and given below. What is the definitive management of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Surgical repositioning of the ureter Explanation: The retrocaval ureter is a congenital anomaly where the ureter passes behind the IVC causing obstruction. Surgical repositioning of the ureter anterior to the IVC is the definitive treatment to relieve the obstruction. Retrocaval Ureter: Cause: Rare congenital anomaly due to an abnormal development of the embryonic venous system (persistence of right

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with intermittent left flank pain and episodes of gross hematuria. Imaging reveals a dilated renal pelvis with a narrowed ureteropelvic junction. Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pyeloplasty Explanation: Pyeloplasty is the surgical procedure of choice for correcting PUJ obstruction. It involves reconstructing the ureteropelvic junction to relieve the obstruction, restoration of normal urine flow, and prevent further kidney damage. Pelviureteric Junction (PUJ) obstruction is a condition where the flow of urine from the renal pelvis into the ureter is impeded due to a narrowing or blockage at the junction between the renal pelvis and the ureter. Causes: Congenital Acquired Atresia/stenosis - Developmental anomaly that leads to an intrinsic narrowing Aberrant left renal artery - The presence of an abnormal blood vessel compressing the junction externally Scarring from previous infections Kidney stones (most common) Surgery - stricture formation Clinical Features: Intermittent Flank Pain - increased fluid intake or diuresis, which increases urine production and pressure at the obstruction site. Hematuria - if there are associated kidney stones. Recurrent Urinary Tract Infections Hydronephrosis - may be asymptomatic in the early stages. Investigations: Ultrasound: Can reveal hydronephrosis without dilation of the ureter below the obstruction. Diuretic Renal Scan (DTPA Scan) - Investigation of choice: A DTPA scan evaluates renal function and drainage, helping to quantify the severity of obstruction. Whittaker’s Test: This is an invasive pressure-flow study used if the DTPA Scan is equivocal, to differentiate between true obstruction and non-obstructive hydronephrosis by measuring the pressure gradient across the PUJ. Magnetic Resonance Urography (MRU): Helps to pinpoint the location and cause of the obstruction. Treatment: Surgical Treatment: Anderson-Hynes Dismembered Pyeloplasty (Option C) : Gold-standard treatment for PUJ obstruction. The procedure involves cutting out the narrowed segment and reattaching the healthy ureter to the renal pelvis, ensuring a wide and unobstructed passage. Foley V-Y Pyeloplasty: When there is a short segment of obstruction or if the pelvis is intrarenal (within the kidney tissue). Flap Pyeloplasty (Spiral or Vertical): Used in specific cases where the obstruction involves a small segment or an intrarenal pelvis. A flap of renal pelvis tissue is used to widen the narrowed area. Endoscopic Treatment (Option D) : Endopyelotomy: Using a laser or electrocautery - an incision is made within the PUJ via an endoscope to relieve the obstruction. Balloon Dilatation: A balloon is inflated at the site of the obstruction to widen the narrowed junction. Observation (Option B) : In asymptomatic patients with mild hydronephrosis, regular monitoring with imaging and renal function tests might be sufficient. Percutaneous nephrostomy (Option A) : This is a temporary measure for relieving obstruction in emergency cases, not a definitive treatment for PUJ obstruction.

questions.question: A 20-year-old pregnant woman undergoes an ultrasound at 22 weeks' gestation. The scan reveals severe oligohydramnios and the fetal kidneys are not visualized. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in the fetus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pulmonary hypoplasia Explanation: In bilateral renal agenesis , the absence of fetal kidneys leads to a lack of amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios), which is crucial for lung development. This results in underdeveloped lungs - pulmonary hypoplasia - leading to respiratory failure at birth. Renal agenesis is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of one or both kidneys. The bladder is usually absent. Bilateral renal agenesis causes Potter syndrome and is typically fatal. Potter syndrome is associated with: Oligohydramnios Pulmonary hypoplasia Potter facies Limb deformities - clubfoot or other positional abnormalities. Growth restriction Medullary sponge kidney (MSK) (Option C) : A congenital, autosomal recessive condition. Characterized by cystic dilatation of the renal collecting tubules, typically in the medulla, giving the medulla a sponge-like or honeycomb appearance. It can be bilateral, unilateral, or affect a single papilla. Diagnosis: Excretory urograms or contrast-enhanced CT scans show dilated tubules near the calyces with possible radiopaque material. Intravenous pyelography- bristles of brush appearance, bouquet of flowers appearance. Presentation: Hematuria. Increased risk of urinary infections and kidney stones due to urinary stasis. Hypertrophy, hypercalcemia, nephrocalcinosis (deposition of calcium in renal parenchyma). Treatment and Prognosis: No specific treatment; focus on managing complications such as infections and stones. Most patients have a good prognosis.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman with a history of tuberous sclerosis complex with angiomyolipoma (AML) presents with a sudden onset of severe left flank pain. On examination, she is hypotensive and has a tender left flank. Imaging reveals a large hemorrhage in the left kidney extending into the perirenal space. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Wunderlich syndrome Explanation: Wunderlich syndrome is a rare, life-threatening condition characterized by spontaneous, non-traumatic renal hemorrhage into the subcapsular and perirenal spaces typically associated with renal angiomyolipomas (AMLs). In patients with renal angiomyolipoma, particularly those associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) , the risk of hemorrhage is heightened , leading to symptoms such as flank pain, hypotension, and tenderness. Angiomyolipomas (AMLs) Arise from Perivascular epithelioid cells Types Most renal AMLs are asymptomatic , discovered incidentally on imaging. Sporadic AMLs: Present in the 4th-6th decades, typically small, solitary, and slow-growing. TSC-associated AMLs: Present earlier (3rd-4th decades), larger, multiple, bilateral, and tend to grow. Symptoms Common symptoms : Abdominal or flank pain, hematuria, hypertension, anemia, and impaired kidney function, usually due to hemorrhage. Hemorrhage: Severe complication. Wunderlich syndrome : nontraumatic kidney hemorrhage. Risk factors for hemorrhage: AML size (>6 cm), increased vascularity, large intralesional aneurysms (>5 mm), and exophytic growth pattern. Risk Factors for AML Complications Pregnancy: Increased risk of hemorrhage due to hormonal changes, increased blood volume, and cardiac output. TSC-associated AMLs: Higher risk of CKD and ESKD, often due to nephrectomy or embolization. Epithelioid AMLs: Potential for malignant transformation, metastasis, and local recurrence. Diagnosis CT: (Investigation of choice) Presence of intralesional fat. Ultrasound: Bright echogenic mass lesion on account of the high fat content. Used for monitoring AML size. MRI: T1 and T2 hyperintensity with enhancement on gadolinium administration. In Phase/opposed phase imaging: India ink artifact. Useful mainly in fat poor AML. Biopsy: Indicated if diagnosis is uncertain via imaging or malignancy is suspected. Immunocytochemical analysis: Useful for differentiating AML from RCC, using markers like HMB-45 and melan-A. Treatment Observation: Suitable for tumors <4 cm Nephron-Sparing Surgery(Partial nephrectomy): Preferred for larger tumors or those with a high risk of bleeding Angioembolization: Main treatment for acute hemorrhage, involves blocking blood flow to the tumor. Medications: mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and sirolimus are useful, especially in cases associated with tuberous sclerosis complex. Pyelonephritis (Option A) typically presents with symptoms such as fever, chills, and flank pain, but does not typically cause a large

questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease? respectively

options.A: The disease involves a mutation in the PKD1 and PKD2 genes on chromosomes 4 and 16
options.B: Hypertension is the most common manifestation
options.C: Cysts can be seen in the organs such as the ovary, and pancreas in patients with ADPKD
options.D: The most common extrarenal manifestation is polycystic liver disease

questions.explanation: 4 and 16 respectively Correct Answer: A) The disease involves a mutation in the PKD1 and PKD2 genes on chromosomes 4 and 16 respectively. Explanation: Mutation in ADPKD is in the PKD1 gene on Chromosome 16 and the PKD2 gene on Chromosome 4 . Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) Definition Characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys. Inheritance Autosomal Dominant Involvement of chromosome 16 (PKD1) and 4 (PKD2) Abnormal protein- Polycystin Both kidneys are replaced by multiple cysts Pathogenesis Both kidneys are replaced by multiple cysts The kidney loses its function of the concentration of urine Cysts in kidney → Compression of blood vessels → Activation of RAAS → Hypertension Clinical Features (Intrarenal) Most common manifestation is hypertension (Option B) Polyuria, Nocturia, Hematuria Nephrolithiasis Chronic renal failure (Usually in the 5th to 6th decade) Any compression in the pelvicalyceal system will lead to HIS (Hydronephrosis; Infection; Stone) → Hematuria Clinical Features (Extrarenal) Polycystic Liver Disease (Most common) (Option D) Cyst in Ovary, Pancreas, Spleen (Option C) Berry Aneurysm Mitral Valve prolapse The most common cause of death is cardiovascular Disorders Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 994, 995

questions.question: A 65-year-old man with a history of working in a dye factory for 30 years presents with flank pain and gross hematuria. Urinalysis confirms the presence of blood, and cytology shows atypical cells. A retrograde urogram was done given in the image below. He was diagnosed with carcinoma of the renal pelvis. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the diagnosis?

options.A: The radiographic image shows the Goblet sign.
options.B: Patients most commonly present with flank pain
options.C: CT urography is the investigation of choice for diagnosis
options.D: The most common histological type is transitional cell carcinoma

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Patients most commonly present with flank pain Explanation: The most common symptom with which carcinoma of the renal pelvis presents is painless gross hematuria . Carcinoma of the renal

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician with a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging studies reveal a large renal tumor and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Wilms tumor. Which of the following statements regarding Wilms tumor is correct?

options.A: Chemotherapy is contraindicated in Wilms tumor due to the young age of the patients
options.B: The most common site of metastasis in patients with Wilms tumor is the Liver.
options.C: A multimodal approach including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation is typically used.
options.D: The route of spread is mostly lymphatic for metastasis of tumor foci.

questions.explanation: typically used. Correct Answer: C) A multimodal approach including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation is typically used Explanation: Wilms tumor requires a multimodal approach for treatment depending on histology and staging of tumor foci and clinical response of the patients. Clinical Presentation Triad: Asymptomatic abdominal mass (MC presentation) Fever (disappears after tumor resection) Hematuria (Gross/Microscopic) Rarely : Pain Investigations USG- Primary investigation CECT- Investigation of choice. MRI - For better soft tissue visualization. Treatment Treatment approach varies based on stage and histology- Multimodal approach Surgery : Radical nephrectomy or nephron-sparing surgery Chemotherapy : VCD regimen (Option A) Vincristine, Cyclophosphamide, Dactinomycin/Doxorubicin Radiation therapy : For higher stages or unfavorable histology Staging I. Disease confined to the kidney and completely resectable II . Tumor extends beyond the kidney but can be excised completely IlI . Residual disease after resection with positive lymph nodes and massive spillage IV . Blood-borne metastasis V . Bilateral disease Prognosis Most important Prognostic Factor - Histology > Stage Metastasis Mainly through a hematogenous route into: (Option D) Lungs (MC) (Option B) Liver Bones (Rarely) Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1012 & 1013

questions.question: A 2-year-old male child presents with severe proteinuria, ambiguous genitalia, and hypertension. His karyotype is 46XY, and genetic testing reveals a missense mutation in the WT1 gene. Imaging studies show a unilateral renal mass. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's clinical presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Denys-Drash syndrome with gonadal dysgenesis Explanation: The patient's severe proteinuria, ambiguous genitalia, hypertension, and WT1 gene mutation, along with the presence of a renal mass, are characteristic of Denys-Drash syndrome. Wilms' Tumor or Nephroblastoma Most common malignant pediatric renal tumor. Mostly unilateral but can be bilateral. Caused by mutations in WT1 and WT2 genes on chromosome 11. Syndromes Associated with Wilms' Tumor: Denys-Drash Syndrome (DDS): Triad of Wilms' tumor , diffuse mesangial sclerosis leading to early-onset nephrotic syndrome, and male pseudohermaphroditism (ambiguous genitalia in a genetically male patient with 46XY karyotype). Caused by missense mutations in the WT1 gene on chromosome 11p13, which disrupt normal kidney and gonadal development. Typically present with severe proteinuria, ambiguous genitalia, and a high risk of developing Wilms' tumor, usually by the age of 3 years. WAGR Syndrome: Includes W ilms' tumor, A niridia (absence of the iris), G enitourinary anomalies , and Mental R etardation . Caused by a deletion in the 11p13 region of the WT1 gene. Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome (BWS): BWS is an overgrowth disorder characterized by macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, organomegaly, omphalocele , and increased risk of Wilms tumor. Associated with genetic and epigenetic changes in the 11p15 region , which includes genes like IGF2 . They do not exhibit the nephropathy or ambiguous genitalia seen in DDS. (Option A) Perlman Syndrome: A rare congenital overgrowth syndrome characterized by nephroblastomatosis, macrosomia, umbilical hernia, and facial dysmorphism , with a high risk of Wilms tumor. (Option D) It involves mutations in the DIS3L2 gene. Frasier Syndrome (Option C) : Presents with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) leading to slowly progressive nephropathy and an increased risk of gonadoblastoma . Wilms tumor is rare in this syndrome. Caused by mutations in the WT1 gene , specifically involving intron 9 splicing. Patients often present with proteinuria and renal insufficiency, along with gonadal dysgenesis. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 2091, 2092

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with painless hematuria and a palpable mass in the left flank. Imaging studies reveal a renal mass measuring 8 cm with evidence of invasion into the renal vein but no involvement of surrounding lymph nodes or distant metastasis. According to the TNM staging system, what is the most appropriate stage of this renal cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Stage III Explanation: In the given clinical scenario: The tumor has invaded the renal vein, which corresponds to T3a. There is no lymph node involvement (N0) or distant metastasis (M0). Therefore, according to the TNM staging system, the patient's RCC is classified as T3aN0M0- Stage III. Category Code Description Tumor Tx Primary tumors cannot be assessed T0 No evidence of a primary tumor T1 Tumor ≤ 7 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the kidney T1a Tumor ≤ 4 cm T1b Tumor >4 cm but ≤ 7 cm T2 Tumor >7 cm, limited to the kidney T2a Tumor >7 cm but ≤ 10 cm T2b Tumor >10 cm T3 The tumor extends into major veins or perinephric tissues but not into the ipsilateral adrenal gland and not beyond Gerota’s fascia T3a The tumor extends into the renal vein or its segmental branches or invades perirenal and/or renal sinus fat but not beyond Gerota’s fascia T3b Tumor extends into the vena cava below the diaphragm T3c Tumor extends into the vena cava above the diaphragm or invades the wall of the vena cava T4 Tumor invades beyond Gerota’s fascia (including contiguous extension into the ipsilateral adrenal gland) Nodes Nx Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed N0 No regional lymph node metastasis N1 Metastasis in regional lymph node(s) Mets M0 No distant metastasis M1 Distant metastasis present Stage Grouping: Stage I: T1, N0, M0 Stage II: T2, N0, M0 Stage III: T1 or T2, N1, M0 T3, N0 or N1, M0 Stage IV: T4 or M1, any N

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman with a history of smoking presents with a sudden onset of headaches and visual disturbances. A CT scan shows a 5 cm mass in the left kidney. Which of the following is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Polycythemia Explanation: Polycythemia in this patient is likely due to ectopic erythropoietin production by renal cell carcinoma, which is a known paraneoplastic manifestation. The sudden onset of symptoms like headaches and visual disturbances can be attributed to the increased blood viscosity caused by polycythemia. Clinical Features of Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC): Classic symptoms such as hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable abdominal mass - “ TOO - LATE” TRIAD seen in 10% of patients with advanced disease. Systemic symptoms like weight loss, fever, and fatigue can also occur. In advanced stages, RCC may metastasize to the lungs, bones, and brain. A non-reducing varicocele, referred to as a suspicious varicocele, may indicate the presence of renal cell carcinoma (RCC), often due to a thrombus originating from the left RCC. Paraneoplastic Manifestations: Elevated ESR . Hypercalcemia: The ectopic production of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by the tumor, leads to increased calcium levels in the blood. This can cause symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and confusion (Option B) . Hypertension: Hypertension in RCC can be due to increased renin production by the tumor or as a result of polycythemia. (Option C) Cushing’s disease: Although less common, Cushing's syndrome can occur as a paraneoplastic manifestation due to ectopic production of ACTH by the tumor, leading to elevated cortisol levels. Addison’s disease is not generally caused by RCC (Option A) . Stauffer's syndrome: (Non metastatic reversible hepatitis) RCC patient with jaundice - Raised Bilirubin, ALP. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 1482

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with an incidental finding of a renal mass on imaging. The mass shows an enhancing appearance on cross-sectional imaging with a central stellate scar. A biopsy is inconclusive, and the mass is surgically removed. Histopathological examination reveals granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm within the tumor cells, negative for cytokeratin 7. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Renal Oncocytoma Explanation: Renal Oncocytoma is characterized by granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm due to abundant mitochondria (oncocytes). The enhancing mass with a central stellate scar is are the suggestive feature. Renal Oncocytoma Definition & Prevalence Benign renal tumor with oncocytes, characterized by granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm. Accounts for ~5% of all renal tumors. Clinical Presentation Typically occurs in the seventh decade of life, more common in males. Can coexist with RCC in ~10% of cases Diagnosis CECT : ( Investigation of choice): Presents as an enhancing mass, while not pathognomonic, can suggest oncocytoma: Central Stellate Scarring: The presence of a star-shaped scar within the tumor. Spoke Wheel Appearance : A characteristic pattern observed during the angiographic phase of imaging. Confirmation of Diagnosis Confirmed post-surgical removal and histopathological examination of oncocytes. Differentiation from chromophobe RCC (eosinophilic variant) may require immunohistochemistry, where chromophobe RCC stains positive for cytokeratin 7 and oncocytoma is positive. Treatment & Prognosis Nephron-sparing surgery ( partial nephrectomy ) is the preferred treatment due to its benign nature. Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma (Option A) typically has cells with clear cytoplasm due to the loss of lipids, and it does not commonly present with a central scar. Chromophobe Renal Cell Carcinoma (Option C) usually lacks the central stellate scar and has a different histological appearance with more distinct cell borders and perinuclear halos, staining positive for cytokeratin 7. Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma (Option D) often has a papillary architecture and cells with more foamy or pale cytoplasm, and the presence of a central scar is not typical.
